If we can refactor, I'll create a separate patch to reduce the duplication in the definitions."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-09-06 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-09-06 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@jrd

Yes, I envision that there could be another filter that will exec another program passed in via the command line.  I made the base class return an empty list for the second set of args so that the filter would always fail until the subclass overrode it with a more specific version.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-09-06 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-09-06 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Can we refactor the filers mechanism so that we can define the filter files with common one and specific one which can include the common one? This way, we will be able not to define the same filters in multiple filters files. I think we can do it in a separate change.'}, {'account_id': 2974, 'date': '2012-09-06 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I see no obvious problems.

I'm not sure I'm qualified to give a thumbs-up yet, but I believe it's solid, modulo a few questions.

In the new ExecArgs filter class, it looks like you're returning an empty list from exec_args().  But in the added logic in match_filter() it looks like you're special casing ExecFilter and doing an additional check on the args being exec'ed.  There's probably a subtlety there which I'm missing w/r/t what's in that inner arglist.  Hint?

[later]  Ok, I think I see.  You're specilizing in IpNetnsExecFilter.  So when it's one of those, you'll have an inner command to filter.

Do you envision other subclasses of ExecFilter which would extend this metaphor?  Do you envision having filters which use ExecFilter directly?

Re the other comments about restructuring common parts of filters:  Bob and I were kicking around the idea of breaking out the filters for the various plugins into different subdirs.  Ie /etc/quantum/rootwrap.d/<plugin>/whatever.filters.  That would allow for more fine-grained control of which filters are available to which plugins, which is likely better for security.  If we decided to do that, we'd want to take that into account when structuring the include-common-bits part.  Probably by making path include /etc/quantum/rootwrap.d/common."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-06 01:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
add rootwrap filters to wrap ip netns exec

fixes bug 1044083

This patch adds specific filters for the ip command. The first filter
matches ip with any subcomand except netns exec.  The second filter
matches "ip netns exec" and then relies on the caller (match_filter) to
verify the sub-command against the other filters. Matching the
subcommand separately allows for a single set of filter definitions that
work with and without namespaces.

Change-Id: Ifd0378dc3461f84867efb3cb60396d9cfa9e582d

commit_message:
Skip tests in OSX due to readlink compat

Although greadlink can be installed on OSX, there is not
compatibility in the code so the tests should be skipped until
OpenStack supports running this code on OSX/BSD.

Fixes bug 1037835

Change-Id: Iddaba950f9f8b3823bd62b59b36e08aff4a979f8

[{'created': '2012-08-28 20:05:06.000000000', 'message': 'Force db_auto_create to False in bin/glance-manage

When interacting with the db migration tool, bin/glance-manage,
we cannot depend on the behavior of auto-creating database tables.
This plays havoc with the migrations that also add those tables. It
is better practice to prevent anything automatic from happening
while running db_sync and to explicitly depend on the migration
scripts.

Fixes bug 1042925

Change-Id: Id93283905256247bdd2663b799d41a7925804542

commit_message:
Remove db auto-creation magic from glance-manage

This removes the reliance of glance-manage db_sync on configure_db
calling register_models.

Fixes bug 1042925

Change-Id: Id93283905256247bdd2663b799d41a7925804542

commit_message:
Makes deployed APIs configurable

Uses config options enable_v1_api and enable_v2_api
to control which APIs have been deployed.
(Thanks markwash for all the help)

Fixes bug 1043497

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-05 22:45:37.000000000', 'message': 'restart dnsmasq when subnet cidr set changes

fixes bug 1045828

The original bug occurred because the set of subnet cidrs changed
without a restart of dnsmasq.  As a result, dnsmasq would not respond
with offers for fixed_ips assigned in the unknown cidr ranges even when
the underlying host file had properly updated.

This patch addresses the bug by restarting dnsmasq when the set of
subnet cidrs changes.  When the set does not change, it will reload the
options and allocations.

Change-Id: I0e257208750703f4a32c51d1323786e76e676bb6
'}]
commit_message:
restart dnsmasq when subnet cidr set changes

fixes bug 1045828

The original bug occurred because the set of subnet cidrs changed
without a restart of dnsmasq.  As a result, dnsmasq would not respond
with offers for fixed_ips assigned in the unknown cidr ranges even when
the underlying host file had properly updated.

This patch addresses the bug by restarting dnsmasq when the set of
subnet cidrs changes.  When the set does not change, it will reload the
options and allocations.

Change-Id: I0e257208750703f4a32c51d1323786e76e676bb6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-03 06:08:45.000000000', 'message': "Ensure os-simple-tenant-usage return correct results

Fix bug #1043999

os-simple_tenant_usage will return usage during the period between paramter
'period_start' and paramter 'period_stop'. But it will return incorrect usage
if 'period_stop' > now . So I set period_stop = now if period_stop > now, it
will calculate correct usage during the period between 'period_start' and
min(period_stop, now).

Change-Id: I61c211fd85b729aaeaac6ef24644ee19eb5bb6b0
"}, {'created': '2012-09-04 10:23:31.000000000', 'message': "Fix simple_tenant_usage's handing of future end times

Fixes bug #1043999

simple_tenant_usage returns the usage in the range between the supplied
start and end query parameters. The _hours_for() method calculates the
number of hours the instance was running in this range, even if the end time
is in the future.

By default, python-novaclient requests usage between 4 weeks ago and tomorrow.
This means we a report which accounts for 24 hours of extra running time for
each currently running instance. Fix this by clamping the period of the
returned report at the current time.

Change-Id: I61c211fd85b729aaeaac6ef24644ee19eb5bb6b0
"}, {'created': '2012-09-05 09:44:26.000000000', 'message': "Fix simple_tenant_usage's handing of future end times

Fixes bug #1043999

simple_tenant_usage returns the usage in the range between the supplied
start and end query parameters. The _hours_for() method calculates the
number of hours the instance was running in this range, even if the end time
is in the future.

By default, python-novaclient requests usage between 4 weeks ago and tomorrow.
This means we a report which accounts for 24 hours of extra running time for
each currently running instance. Fix this by clamping the period of the
returned report at the current time.

Change-Id: I61c211fd85b729aaeaac6ef24644ee19eb5bb6b0
"}]
commit_message:
Fix simple_tenant_usage's handing of future end times

Fixes bug #1043999

simple_tenant_usage returns the usage in the range between the supplied
start and end query parameters. The _hours_for() method calculates the
number of hours the instance was running in this range, even if the end time
is in the future.

By default, python-novaclient requests usage between 4 weeks ago and tomorrow.
This means we a report which accounts for 24 hours of extra running time for
each currently running instance. Fix this by clamping the period of the
returned report at the current time.

Change-Id: I61c211fd85b729aaeaac6ef24644ee19eb5bb6b0

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-03 19:13:43.000000000', 'message': "Fix usage-list date range to use UTC time

Fixes bug #1045456

The date range in Nova's os-simple-tenant-usage is expected to be in UTC
time since launch/termination dates are stored in the DB in UTC time and
we use the client supplied parameters to query DB without conversion.

Switch from using datetime.today() to datetime.utcnow() to fix the issue.

Add a test for the default date range.

Import timeutils from openstack-common so we can control the return value
of utcnow() in the tests.

Change-Id: Iac77e3a4cc9561714d1492c54cef931f9764531e
"}]
commit_message:
Fix usage-list date range to use UTC time

Fixes bug #1045456

The date range in Nova's os-simple-tenant-usage is expected to be in UTC
time since launch/termination dates are stored in the DB in UTC time and
we use the client supplied parameters to query DB without conversion.

Switch from using datetime.today() to datetime.utcnow() to fix the issue.

Add a test for the default date range.

Import timeutils from openstack-common so we can control the return value
of utcnow() in the tests.

Change-Id: Iac77e3a4cc9561714d1492c54cef931f9764531e

commit_message:
Speed up creating floating ips.

Previously, we would make two separate DB calls for each floating ip
we created in floating_ip_bulk_create. This was just a little slow
(several hours to create a /16). This patch speeds up floating ip
creation just a little:

$ time bin/nova-manage floating create --ip_range=10.250.0.0/16

real	0m48.766s
user	0m34.342s
sys	0m1.984s

Resolves bug 1023560.

Change-Id: Ie3663440d414b102111178899db0c571769edba8

This is addressed by using utils.xhtml_escape() on purposeful eC2 error
responses and when handling webob.exc.HTTPException.

commit_message:
Escape ec2 XML error responses

Fixes bug 978439

XML error responses to ec2 calls include user supplied data that is not
escaped. This could result in returning invalid XML.

This is addressed by using utils.xhtml_escape() on purposeful eC2 error
responses and when handling webob.exc.HTTPException.

Extended the tests for utils.xhtml_escape() to cover '&', '>', '<' and a tag
look-alike. These conversions are implicit to saxutils.escape().

Change-Id: Icb3e861c6c06c0d9c3b9e2ab1a658581a0fb39c6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-04 22:17:49.000000000', 'message': "Add scope to extra_specs entries, resolve BZ 1039386

Do to conflicts between different scheduler filters it is necessary
to specify a scope for the different keys.  This scope is a leading
string followed by a ':' character, e.g.:

        Foo:bar

is the `bar' entry with scope `Foo'.  For compatibility reasons
entries for the ComputeCapabilities filter have no scope listed.

The Trusted filter will now use the scope `Trust' and the
AggregateInstanceExtraSpecs filter will use the scope `Aggregate'.
Any new filters that utilize the `extra_specs' table will need to
use a unique scope string for any keys they require.

Resolves BZ 1039386

Change-Id: I2466dc3d4de8e9aeb76b294eeda1c939c0413366
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com
"}, {'created': '2012-09-05 15:16:02.000000000', 'message': "Add scope to extra_specs entries, Resolves bug 1039386

Do to conflicts between different scheduler filters it is necessary
to allow an optional scope for the different keys.  This scope is a
leading string followed by a ':' character, e.g.:

        foo:bar

is the `bar' entry with scope `foo'.

The Trusted filter will now use the scope `trust' and the
AggregateInstanceExtraSpecs and ComputeCapabilities filters will
check against any unscoped keys in the `extra_specs' table.
Any new filters that utilize the `extra_specs' table will need to

Change-Id: I2466dc3d4de8e9aeb76b294eeda1c939c0413366
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com
"}, {'created': '2012-09-05 15:39:03.000000000', 'message': "Add scope to extra_specs entries

commit_message:
Add scope to extra_specs entries

Do to conflicts between different scheduler filters it is necessary
to allow an optional scope for the different keys.  This scope is a
leading string followed by a ':' character, e.g.:

        foo:bar

is the `bar' entry with scope `foo'.

The Trusted filter will now use the scope `trust' and the
AggregateInstanceExtraSpecs and ComputeCapabilities filters will
check against any unscoped keys in the `extra_specs' table.
Any new filters that utilize the `extra_specs' table will need to
use a unique scope string for any keys they require.

Resolves bug 1039386

Change-Id: I2466dc3d4de8e9aeb76b294eeda1c939c0413366
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com

allowed_rpc_exception_modules in my default config. This

commit_message:
Add cinder to allowed_rpc_exception_modules.

When configuring Cinder I would rather not have to specify
allowed_rpc_exception_modules in my default config. This
patch updates the default list of allowed_rpc_exception_modules to
include cinder.exception.

Change-Id: Ib7babb1ceb13e86c555947ebc869b50afd7e9b49
(cherry picked from commit 1071b9da480d25e7cee556d7f9b483f8ac258ffb)

commit_message:
Add cinder to allowed_rpc_exception_modules.

When configuring Cinder I would rather not have to specify
allowed_rpc_exception_modules in my default config. This
patch updates the default list of allowed_rpc_exception_modules to
include cinder.exception.

Change-Id: Ib7babb1ceb13e86c555947ebc869b50afd7e9b49

Previously stacks could only be referenced by name. Now, use the canonical
stack identifier to act on them. The identifier can be obtained from the
RPC API by looking it up with identify_stack. In the AWS API, the user

commit_message:
Support lookup of stacks by name or ARN

Previously stacks could only be referenced by name. Now, use the canonical
stack identifier to act on them. The identifier can be obtained from the
RPC API by looking it up with identify_stack. In the AWS API, the user
can pass an ARN that is converted into an identifier.

Change-Id: I29309d12e522ed301c3f6269df5d1d14382b024b
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-05 20:12:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add an identify_stack RPC call

This call converts a stack name into a fully-qualified stack identifier.

This allows us to, e.g., add support for keeping deleted stacks around in
the database while still allowing stack names to be reused, since the
deleted stacks can be referenced using this ID.

Change-Id: Ide19841a92a25d2f6172f19c2627d24ab6d2fd63
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add an identify_stack RPC call

This call converts a stack name into a fully-qualified stack identifier.

This allows us to, e.g., add support for keeping deleted stacks around in
the database while still allowing stack names to be reused, since the
deleted stacks can be referenced using this ID.

Change-Id: Ide19841a92a25d2f6172f19c2627d24ab6d2fd63
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Report StackId in ARN format

In the RPC API, return a full stack identifier instead of just the database
ID of a stack. In the AWS API, convert this to an ARN for the user.

Change-Id: I5c3ede4885c4ac5801cfef49e05695f3d13622da
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-09-05 20:04:13.000000000', 'message': 'Use assertEqual() instead of assert_()

assertEqual(x, y) reports helpful error messages, unlike assert_(x == y)
which reports only that False is not True.

Change-Id: Idbea59dc4dbbe4ac00bad6f358896fbc9401acab
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use assertEqual() instead of assert_()

assertEqual(x, y) reports helpful error messages, unlike assert_(x == y)
which reports only that False is not True.

Change-Id: Idbea59dc4dbbe4ac00bad6f358896fbc9401acab
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat tests : FuncUtils use heat_client in create_stack

Use heat_client (not subprocess) to create the stack,
as this will allow easier testing of the boto_client
library and easier checking of create_stack result

Change-Id: Ic3f710ec2e467bcd2fde1a2451709d444b89aca0
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add option to disable file injection.

Add an option to dsiable file injection into the instances.
Turned off by default this fixes Bug: 833499.

Change-Id: Ia968b36524a104d396e59c61f15dccd68425b85c
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-05 17:23:02.000000000', 'message': 'Sync improvements to config file generator tools.

We made some improvements to the config file generator in
Nova during Folsom including spacing and formatting changes.

This patch merges these into Cinder so we can make use of
them to generate a new sample config file.

Change-Id: I1e1166ac6e2a28cc179223e5af547995f58b36e6
'}]
commit_message:
Sync improvements to config file generator tools.

We made some improvements to the config file generator in
Nova during Folsom including spacing and formatting changes.

This patch merges these into Cinder so we can make use of
them to generate a new sample config file.

Change-Id: I1e1166ac6e2a28cc179223e5af547995f58b36e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-30 00:33:48.000000000', 'message': "Remove bad error message in glance-cache-manage

The error message covering unauthorized requests implies that the
caller hasn't set the appropriate authentication values. What
is more likely is that the values are set but the user just
doesn't have permission to use the tool.

Change-Id: I95f4c1b6fc650b6bf8c11a4e343e1b54c14310f9
"}]
commit_message:
Remove bad error message in glance-cache-manage

The error message covering unauthorized requests implies that the
caller hasn't set the appropriate authentication values. What
is more likely is that the values are set but the user just
doesn't have permission to use the tool.

Change-Id: I95f4c1b6fc650b6bf8c11a4e343e1b54c14310f9

commit_message:

[{'created': '2012-09-05 15:55:12.000000000', 'message': 'Sort UUID lists in test_image_get_all_owned

Ensure UUID list comparison is order-independent, to avoid spurious
failure from the test_image_get_all_owned test case.

Change-Id: I78743a65978b2f1c10adb66b7128c9f438393796
'}]
commit_message:
Sort UUID lists in test_image_get_all_owned

Ensure UUID list comparison is order-independent, to avoid spurious
failure from the test_image_get_all_owned test case.

Change-Id: I78743a65978b2f1c10adb66b7128c9f438393796

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-04 12:39:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix cache not handling backend failures

1) caching_iter doesn't handle backend exceptions:

caching_iter assumes any exception that occurs is the result of being
unable to cache.  Hence the IOError raised from size_checked_iter, which
indicates a problem with the backend, means the caching_iter will
continuing trying to serve non-existent data.  The exception was not
been re-raised in this case, making wsgi keep the connection open and
clients stuck forever waiting for more data.

Raising a GlanceException in size_checked_iter rather than an IOError
allows caching_iter to distinguish between a problem fetching data, and
a problem writing to the cache.

2) Checksum verification happens after cache commit rather than before:

This block was outside the context manager block which meant the
GlanceException was not caught by open_for_write and the rollback didn't
happen.  This resulted in an error been logged, but the bad image still
placed in and subsequently served from the cache.

Also:

* Fix test_gate_caching_iter_bad_checksum - the loop to consume the
  iterator in was in a subroutine that never got called.

* Move test_gate_caching_iter_(good|bad)_checksum into
  ImageCacheTestCase to excercise both the sql and xattr drivers.

* Remove invalid registry_host/registry_port params from
  TestImageCacheXattr/TestImageCacheSqlite setup which caused a failure
  when testing the file on it's own using nosetests.

Fixes bug 1045792

Change-Id: I8aedec347e7f50566c44c5b6c6db424573c5ebaf
"}]
commit_message:
Fix cache not handling backend failures

1) caching_iter doesn't handle backend exceptions:

caching_iter assumes any exception that occurs is the result of being
unable to cache.  Hence the IOError raised from size_checked_iter, which
indicates a problem with the backend, means the caching_iter will
continuing trying to serve non-existent data.  The exception was not
been re-raised in this case, making wsgi keep the connection open and
clients stuck forever waiting for more data.

Raising a GlanceException in size_checked_iter rather than an IOError
allows caching_iter to distinguish between a problem fetching data, and
a problem writing to the cache.

2) Checksum verification happens after cache commit rather than before:

This block was outside the context manager block which meant the
GlanceException was not caught by open_for_write and the rollback didn't
happen.  This resulted in an error been logged, but the bad image still
placed in and subsequently served from the cache.

Also:

* Fix test_gate_caching_iter_bad_checksum - the loop to consume the
  iterator in was in a subroutine that never got called.

* Move test_gate_caching_iter_(good|bad)_checksum into
  ImageCacheTestCase to excercise both the sql and xattr drivers.

* Remove invalid registry_host/registry_port params from
  TestImageCacheXattr/TestImageCacheSqlite setup which caused a failure
  when testing the file on it's own using nosetests.

Fixes bug 1045792

Change-Id: I8aedec347e7f50566c44c5b6c6db424573c5ebaf

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-05 18:16:35.000000000', 'message': 'Do not delete VMs in the HOLD state.

If a VM is in the HOLD state do not transition it to the DELETE state.
This should allow you to set a VM to the HOLD state before tests have
completed and the VM will not be deleted.

Change-Id: I8cc0ca408b4ccf5951399e27c0bfc518fa8ebd1d
'}]
commit_message:
Do not delete VMs in the HOLD state.

If a VM is in the HOLD state do not transition it to the DELETE state.
This should allow you to set a VM to the HOLD state before tests have
completed and the VM will not be deleted.

Change-Id: I8cc0ca408b4ccf5951399e27c0bfc518fa8ebd1d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-05 09:47:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix aggregates test with multi host setup

Fixes bug 1046222.

The aggregate exercise assumed that you have only one compute node, thus
it failed with syntax error for two hosts. With this fix, the exercise
will pick the first compute host, and use that for the tests.

Change-Id: I85d76552295d640e1a9d86fbbed781f15529d047
'}]
commit_message:
Fix aggregates test with multi host setup

Fixes bug 1046222.

The aggregate exercise assumed that you have only one compute node, thus
it failed with syntax error for two hosts. With this fix, the exercise
will pick the first compute host, and use that for the tests.

Change-Id: I85d76552295d640e1a9d86fbbed781f15529d047

commit_message:
Sync importutils changes from openstack-common

Syncs the following changes from stable/folsom:

 769ec65 Don't trap then re-raise ImportError.
 8c74b37 Improve exception from importutils.import_class().
 1fb2361 add import_object_ns function

Change-Id: Ib6046181ec4712702c30c8a8e938fc9a21b1a594

commit_message:
fix issues with Nova security groups and Quantum

bug #1039400

- make quantumv2/api.py fetch actual DHCP server address, which
is needed by firewall layer (otherwise, the gateway IP is
incorrectly used and all DHCP traffic is dropped).
- add missing call from quantumv2/api.py to the security
groups API when a VM is allocated/deallocated.

- Add a vif-driver that is a hybrid of the existing Open vswitch +
linux bridge drivers, which allows OVS quantum plugins to
be compatible with iptables based filtering, in particular, nova
security groups.

- Also clean-up some docstrings in virt/libvirt/vif.py

Change-Id: I7cf5cf09583202a12785b616d18db3ee4bbffee0

commit_message:

 5a56539 Allow non-string items in the creds dict.

 01b4f31 Support for marshalling datetime while preserving microseconds.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-05 01:58:11.000000000', 'message': 'Use bare container_format when VM image in glance was deleted before snapshot

Currently, if VM image in glance was already deleted before snapshot,
nova will attempt to create snapshot image with container_format: None
This cause glance to return error on attempt to upload snapshot.
According to glance docs container_format is not used anywhere in glance
or nova explicitly and it is safe to set it to bare, when you are unsure
which container_format you need to use. Current snapshot logic sets
snapshot disk_format to currently used image_format in absence of
base image in glance.

This resolves bug 921774 without need for snapshot mechanism redesign.

Change-Id: I7beea35120aaeac0837daecdf58f38f62e24454c

commit_message:
Use bare container format by default

Set container_format to bare during libvirt snapshot, when VM image in
glance was deleted. Currently, if VM image in glance was already deleted
before snapshot, nova will attempt to create snapshot image with
container_format: None. This cause glance to return error on attempt to
upload snapshot. According to glance docs container_format is not used
anywhere in glance or nova explicitly and it is safe to set it to bare,
when you are unsure which container_format you need to use.
Current snapshot logic sets snapshot disk_format to currently used
image_format in absence of base image in glance.

This resolves bug 921774 without need for snapshot mechanism redesign.

Change-Id: I7beea35120aaeac0837daecdf58f38f62e24454c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-26 06:18:10.000000000', 'message': "Can run swift-bench across multiple cores/servers.

You run one or more swift-bench-client processes like this:
    $ swift-bench-client 127.0.0.1 20001
    $ swift-bench-client 127.0.0.1 20002

Then you run swift-bench with a new option, --bench-clients (-b), which is a
space-sep list of <IP>:<port> strings, matching each available
swift-bench-client process:
    $ swift-bench -b '127.0.0.1:20001 127.0.0.1:20002'

You get log lines from each client (interleaved) along with a final report
for all clients:
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:06,148 INFO Auth version: 1.0
    127.0.0.1:20001 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:06,148 INFO Auth version: 1.0
    127.0.0.1:20001 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:12,249 INFO 83 PUTS [0 failures], 41.5/s
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:14,430 INFO 74 PUTS [0 failures], 34.3/s
    ...
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:45:18,942 INFO Auth version: 1.0
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:45:20,946 INFO 238 DEL [2 failures], 118.9/s
    swift-bench 2012-08-25 22:45:27,549 INFO 2000 PUTS **FINAL** [0 failures], 56.8/s

commit_message:
Can run swift-bench across multiple cores/servers.

You run one or more swift-bench-client processes like this:
    $ swift-bench-client 127.0.0.1 20001
    $ swift-bench-client 127.0.0.1 20002

Then you run swift-bench with a new option, --bench-clients (-b), which is
specified once for each swift-bench-client:
    $ swift-bench -b 127.0.0.1:20001 -b 127.0.0.1:20002

You get log lines from each client (interleaved) along with a final report
for all clients:
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:06,148 INFO Auth version: 1.0
    127.0.0.1:20001 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:06,148 INFO Auth version: 1.0
    127.0.0.1:20001 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:12,249 INFO 83 PUTS [0 failures], 41.5/s
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:44:14,430 INFO 74 PUTS [0 failures], 34.3/s
    ...
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:45:18,942 INFO Auth version: 1.0
    127.0.0.1:20002 swift-bench-server 2012-08-25 22:45:20,946 INFO 238 DEL [2 failures], 118.9/s
    swift-bench 2012-08-25 22:45:27,549 INFO 2000 PUTS **FINAL** [0 failures], 56.8/s
    swift-bench 2012-08-25 22:45:27,550 INFO 30000 GETS **FINAL** [50 failures], 974.6/s
    swift-bench 2012-08-25 22:45:27,550 INFO 2000 DEL **FINAL** [20 failures], 237.1/s

The concurrency, PUT count, and GET count config settings are divided by
the number of bench_clients.  In other words, the same volume of work is
attempted (vs. not specifying --bench-clients), but it can now span
servers and CPU cores.

Benchmark containers are created (if use_proxy = yes) and deleted (if
delete = yes), with appropriate concurrency, in the initiating
swift-bench process, not any of the swift-bench-client processes.

Change-Id: Idbf31a23093244ab357a9bf77e6031257774f24a

commit_message:
Removed unnecessary call to ensure_export

Removed the extra call to 'ensure_export' from '_copy_image_to_volume' while
creating a volume from an image.

Fixes LP: #1044399

Change-Id: I189a4cb66b965367289c2f677147ee085e431190

* cosmetic cleanups

"}, {'created': '2012-09-04 09:25:08.000000000', 'message': 'Yield to another greenthread after each periodic task

  Partially addresses bug #1045152

  On a heavily loaded compute node, it can be observed that periodic tasks

  running long enough that the scheduler thinks the host is dead.

Change-Id: If2b125708da8298b20497e2e08e52280c102f1e1
'}, {'created': '2012-09-05 05:01:11.000000000', 'message': 'Yield to another greenthread when some time-consuming task finished.

Partially addresses bug #1045152

On a heavily loaded compute node, it can be observed that periodic tasks
take so long to run that the report_state() looping call can be blocked from
running long enough that the scheduler thinks the host is dead.

Reduce the chance of this happening by yielding to another greenthread
after each periodic task has completed and each loop in some methods
that has linear relationship with the number of instances.

Change-Id: If2b125708da8298b20497e2e08e52280c102f1e1
'}]
commit_message:
Yield to another greenthread when some time-consuming task finished.

Partially addresses bug #1045152

On a heavily loaded compute node, it can be observed that periodic tasks
take so long to run that the report_state() looping call can be blocked from
running long enough that the scheduler thinks the host is dead.

Reduce the chance of this happening by yielding to another greenthread
after each periodic task has completed and each loop in some methods
that has linear relationship with the number of instances.

Change-Id: If2b125708da8298b20497e2e08e52280c102f1e1

commit_message:
Allow hard reboot of a soft rebooting instance

Allow hard reboot API calls to succeed if the task status is
soft reboot, but not hard reboot.
This was discussed in the previous change for this bug in
Iae95b121c5c623e1eaa6fba52b13170413722d2d

Fixes bug #944015

Change-Id: I0f78faad524774dbbcad0bf2adafed3802dfeb75

Storing the token body in the database back end is expensive and
not required.  This removes the storage, as well as updates
the Database schema

Bug 1046023

commit_message:
Adds deferred delete extension to API doc

fixes bug 1035484

As per the bug report, the API docs was lacking documentation of the
deferred delete extension introduced in Essex at
blueprint deferred-delete-instance

This patch adds the basic details, with no examples at the moment.

Change-Id: I6c4614a75749008035d6109485251d118e7ead74

[{'created': '2012-09-05 11:51:31.000000000', 'message': 'Check for doc build dependency before building

The import error produced when the sphinxcontrib-httpdomain
package is missing is for sphinxcontrib.autohttp.flask,
but the package to install is sphinxcontrib-httpdomain.
This check produces a more useful error message than
allowing Sphinx to report the import error by itself.

Change-Id: I2f53761da47b593e74d12c7dd213e69e4d71db21
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Check for doc build dependency before building

The import error produced when the sphinxcontrib-httpdomain
package is missing is for sphinxcontrib.autohttp.flask,
but the package to install is sphinxcontrib-httpdomain.
This check produces a more useful error message than
allowing Sphinx to report the import error by itself.

Change-Id: I2f53761da47b593e74d12c7dd213e69e4d71db21
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-29 16:56:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add kernel/ramdisk_id, instance_uuid to v2 schema

Nova depends on a few properties to be able to interact with
images in Glance effectively. The three added in this patch
are kernel_id, ramdisk_id and instance_uuid. These properties
are just being added to the default v2 schema, so they can
be overwritten if a consumer decides they need to.

Fixes bug 1039818

Change-Id: I5cfd5f0b5c8d1d526d56d99de738f9271aa641c1
'}]
commit_message:
Add kernel/ramdisk_id, instance_uuid to v2 schema

Nova depends on a few properties to be able to interact with
images in Glance effectively. The three added in this patch
are kernel_id, ramdisk_id and instance_uuid. These properties
are just being added to the default v2 schema, so they can
be overwritten if a consumer decides they need to.

Fixes bug 1039818

Change-Id: I5cfd5f0b5c8d1d526d56d99de738f9271aa641c1

Just put some thoughts here.

1. How about other way instead of creating temporary files? Obviously it consumes additional spaces.

Since pipe is inherently non-seekable, so far I've not come up with other ideas to implement.

2. How about adding proper logic in python-glance client to handle this case?

python-glance client depends on seek system call to determine image size. It's hard to determine for the piped input, and not worth the effort. Using temporary file seems to be the best solution."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-09-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

[{'created': '2012-08-21 09:00:31.000000000', 'message': 'Use tempfile instead of process substitution when uploading *.img.gz image

Fixes bug 1039409

The process substitution, aka. <(command) is a non-seekable input, [1]
which cause glance client calculated wrong image size, which in turn
causes *.img.gz iamge upload failure in stack.sh

This change use temporary file to correctly handle this case.

[1]. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_substitution#Limitations

Change-Id: I4b6836a7f9a34cb190a8b29904e2df3dd98b3ef3
'}, {'created': '2012-08-21 09:03:57.000000000', 'message': 'Fix for glance image-create of *.img.gz files

which cause glance client calculated wrong image size, which in turn
causes *.img.gz iamge upload failure in stack.sh

This change use temporary file to correctly handle this case.

[1]. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_substitution#Limitations

Change-Id: I4b6836a7f9a34cb190a8b29904e2df3dd98b3ef3
'}]
commit_message:
Fix for glance image-create of *.img.gz files

Fixes bug 1039409

The process substitution, aka. <(command), is a non-seekable input, [1]
which cause glance client calculated wrong image size, which in turn
causes *.img.gz iamge upload failure in stack.sh

This change use temporary file to correctly handle this case.

[1]. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_substitution#Limitations

Change-Id: I4b6836a7f9a34cb190a8b29904e2df3dd98b3ef3

[{'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2012-05-17 17:16:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Please use try and finally blocks to ensure no clean up of resources created during the tests:

try:
create sometbing

finally:
delete something"}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2012-05-17 17:20:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

sorry that should have said:
Please use try and finally blocks to ensure clean up of resources created during the test'}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2012-05-17 17:21:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-05-17 22:31:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd actually like to see the issue of resources dealt with, especially for a new set of tests. While effective, the try/finally wrapping is verbose and repetitive.  One solution that I've seen in other submissions would be to create lists of entities to teardown at the end of tests that exists at the class level and managed through the class setup/teardown fixtures."}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2012-05-17 22:45:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Darryl,

IHMO sometimes it makes sense for the tests to create the resource itself and not setup. For example, in test_container_services.py if would make sense for the test to create the container and not setup.

Additionally, having the tests act as true independent unit tests we don't unnecessarily create resources when not needed, if a test is skipped (i.e. I create 10 containers in setup but I only run one test that uses one of the containers marked @smoke)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-05-18 18:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

FWIW, the base TestCase classes that I put in the smoke test merge proposal solve this issue of resource tracking (removes the need for try: finally: blocks and instead cleans everything up together)

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7069/'}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2012-05-18 22:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

All,

How do you guys feel about creating resources up front in setup that may never be used in the tests if they are skipped?

The trade off for me is that we would be spending extra time in setup and the test time would be much longer.'}, {'account_id': 1795, 'date': '2012-05-21 17:33:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

There are duplicates in tests . Container and objects have overlapping and duplicate tests . Need to clean that.'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-05-22 16:41:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(17 inline comments)

See attached comments. Going in the right direction, just needs a bit more work"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-30 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add nosehtmloutput as a test dependency.

Adding nosehtmloutput as a test dependency allows nose to output its
results to an html file. This will be used by Jenkins to save logs on
a different server.

Change-Id: Ia552d8e3acbab4c7d8a2cc546e2af1d7e7cbacca

gholt's mentioned he's working his way through it so he'll probably have a nice long list of fixes soon.  might be worth waiting to review it till gholt posts his review in case I need to fix a ton of stuff."}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-08-02 15:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

*bump*'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-08-07 19:38:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I would've expected HEAD paths to match GET paths. So, GET /ring/object.tar.gz would have a corresponding HEAD /ring/object.tar.gz but the way it's coded I'd HEAD /ring/object which seems weird. Actually, this makes sense to me now since a GET /object gives a listing with the x-ring-hash header, so HEAD just does the same (kinda). The documentation of /list threw me. Generally though, GETs should also allow HEADs. Most the time this is just implemented with the same function that just suppresses the content right at the end.

None of the requests are logged, but they should be.

GET /ring/object/list doesn't seem to work. Seems the target in the get method is 'object/list' not 'object' that it's checking for. Probably a documentation bug? Also, it seems to do a backup when doing a listing.

Also, I couldn't get search to work until I realized I had to set "Content-Type: application/json". Maybe provide curl examples to better show what's intended?

Missing ring-builder-key should 401 or 403.

An empty list should probably return json [] (like an empty container does in Swift itself).

Failures need to be more descriptive. It's really hard to debug what a client is doing wrong when everything returns the exact same way. Just a quick text/plain content of things like "Missing Ring-Builder-LastHash" and stuff would really help.

Also, why no X- on some headers and X- on others? LastHash instead of Last-Hash?

I'm confused why listing devices gives me a new x-ring-hash every time. Also, I think that's the hash of the builder, not the ring. Not sure if that matters exactly, but it did throw me a bit.

Keep your eye on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10846/ which would add a builder.get_ring that should be used here.

That's all for now. :)'}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-08-14 08:24:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-14 08:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-29 07:33:10.000000000', 'message': "Implements a basic ring builder web service

This implements a basic ring builder web service via middleware
thats suitable for running on an internal proxy.

- Most operations lock the builder files to ensure that the state
  doesn't change. This makes the service unsuitable for high
  concurrency.
- At this stage theres no saftey checks between the web serivce and
  swift-ring-builder. That means they can trample on each others changes
  if both are being used at the same time!
- Most operations require that you provide what you expect the on disk
  md5sum of the builder file to be. This is to ensure that you only
  modify a builder who's state you are aware of.
- A rebalance call is included but should not be used with larger rings
  since they can take a significant amount of time to rebalance
  (minutes). Since a rebalance and ring deployment is typically
  managed through other means (dedicated service, chef, etc) rebalance
  is only implemented here as a courtesy.
- Implements blueprint ring-builder-server

Change-Id: I8946a90129565e317424bdff8988f0f3e4615a6c

commit_message:
Implements a basic ring builder web service

This implements a basic ring builder web service via middleware
thats suitable for running on an internal proxy.

- Most operations lock the builder files to ensure that the state
  doesn't change. This makes the service unsuitable for high
  concurrency.
- At this stage theres no safety checks between the web service and
  swift-ring-builder. That means they can trample on each others changes
  if both are being used at the same time. So don't do that.
- Most operations require that you provide what you expect the on disk
  md5sum of the builder file to be. This is to ensure that you only
  modify a builder who's state you are aware of.
- A rebalance call is included but should not be used with larger rings
  since they can take a significant amount of time to rebalance
  (minutes). Since a rebalance and ring deployment is typically
  managed through other means (dedicated service, chef, etc) rebalance
  is only implemented for completeness. Down the road I think it would
  be handy to add hooks to hand off a rebalance task to third party
  system's (a queue, write to a file, etc).
- Implements blueprint ring-builder-server
- Like statsd integration this is a work in progress. End points, methods,
  etc may change.
- As brought up in the irc channel this change also introduces mock as a
  dependency for unittest's

Change-Id: I8946a90129565e317424bdff8988f0f3e4615a6c

commit_message:
Encode headers in v1 API to utf-8

We're getting data from the registry via JSON, which means the values
are of the unicode type. We want to output utf-8, otherwise this won't
work if we use glance through mod_wsgi.

Fix bug 1042078.

Change-Id: Iadb215003db57ab25d9919341e6aba195835531c

commit_message:
Makes sure new flavors default to is_public=True

The default for is_public is true in the database, but new flavors
created through the extension was defaulting is_public=None and passing
it through to the db layer where it gets converted to False.

This patch fixes the issue by defaulting is_public to True at the api
layer. Incldes a broken test to verify.

Fixes bug 1046040

Change-Id: I4c361c0055a14de29e364868074e17cf3ec23220

[{'created': '2012-09-04 21:55:49.000000000', 'message': "Optimizes flavor_access to not make a db request

We are now caching the flavor object in the request so we don't
need to make another db request. Note that there is further refactoring
possible but I wanted to keep the changes small to minimize chance for
regression. Also, no need to check for not found since we will have
errored much earlier if the flavor doesn't exist.

This change is necessary to create a failing test for bug 1046040

Change-Id: I718203b33a192575288057dd4631a9aa3086b567
"}]
commit_message:
Optimizes flavor_access to not make a db request

We are now caching the flavor object in the request so we don't
need to make another db request. Note that there is further refactoring
possible but I wanted to keep the changes small to minimize chance for
regression. Also, no need to check for not found since we will have
errored much earlier if the flavor doesn't exist.

This change is necessary to create a failing test for bug 1046040

Change-Id: I718203b33a192575288057dd4631a9aa3086b567

[{'created': '2012-09-04 22:29:00.000000000', 'message': 'Automatically convert device names

In the past, users have been able to specify xvda or xvdb and it
has worked. We are now validating device names against the expected
name from the backend, and this causes confusion, especially for lxc
which expecting device names to be /dev/a /dev/b /dev/c etc.

This patch addresses the issue by automatically converting between
different formats. The proper format for the backend will be returned
by the api. Includes tests to verify that the conversion works and
that the lxc values work as expected.

Fixes bug 1046020

commit_message:
Automatically convert device names

In the past, users have been able to specify xvda or xvdb and it
has worked. We are now validating device names against the expected
name from the backend, and this causes confusion, especially for lxc
which expecting device names to be /dev/a /dev/b /dev/c etc.

This patch addresses the issue by automatically converting between
different formats. The proper format for the backend will be returned
by the api. Includes tests to verify that the conversion works and
that the lxc values work as expected.

Fixes bug 1046020

Change-Id: Iffa552ba05f89f70b6fb93043edf8882c8412215

commit_message:
Fall back to UDP if /dev/log does not exist.

If /dev/log does not exist, swift.common.utils.get_logger would fail as
it only handles the situation where /dev/log isn't a socket.

Fixes bug 1045820

Change-Id: I2c33e0fa7f88f03d5b0495779832ed4de7c496da

Regarding the OVS, if there is tunneling enabled you may have to delete the br-tun.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-09-05 00:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 inline comments)

I like this patch, and more in general the concept to have a garbage collector that we can expand in the next release.

I wonder if we can let the user know whether the cleanup utility successfully deleted all candidate namespaces.

Also, it would be great if you can clarify how the wait will avoid confusion between new namespaces and old ones to be collected. What if a new namespace is brought up while the cleanup utility is waiting?'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-09-05 00:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Create utility to clean-up netns.

Fixes bug 1035366

Adds namespace clean up utility called quantum-netns-cleanup which can be used
to remove old namespaces.

The --force option can be used to remove all Quantum namespaces and any
remaining devices.  The force option is should not be run on a live Quantum
systems.  It is intended for cleaning up devstack a after running
unstack.sh (ideally this will be added to unstack.sh in the future).

Example cmd line when cleaning up a devstack install:
quantum-netns-cleanup --config-file /etc/quantum/quantum.conf \
--config-file /etc/quantum/dhcp_agent.ini --force

Change-Id: I6cf153df21e83bff2cde816db12b22102d1ba698

"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-08-20 22:48:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The unit test failure here is a tricky one to solve.

The test that is failing depends on the app exiting as quickly as possible because of an invalid default_store option. This happens when the paste app is loaded and glance.api.v1.images:Controller.verify_scheme_or_exit exits. It expects the process to exit before it has bound the listening port, because of how glance.tests.functional.__init__:FunctionalTest.wait_for_servers is implemented.

This patch delays the initialization of the app now until after the process (potentially) forks, which is also after the listening port is bound (which must happen before the fork).

As a result, the test fails when it sees the port is listening before the tested process checks the default_store option and exits.

Ultimately, the goal of delaying configuring the database as late as possible (to fix the bug) conflicts with the goals of the test, which is to fail as early as possible (before the port is listening).

Possible solutions.
1) Use pre-patch style of initializing the application but delay configuring the database until it's first used (similar to nova).
2) Change the tests to not use a listening port as an indicator that the test has failed.
3) Force the database connection to be reopened after fork.

Option 1 is a significant change to how glance works, but there is some precedent since this is how nova works. It also has the downside of failing kind of late if the database connection isn't configured properly, or the database isn't working.

Option 2 would require some significant changes to how the tests work. I also kind of like the existing test since code should fail as fast as possible. I'm also not sure what an appropriate alternative method of checking if the process actually started would be.

Option 3 is a little hacky since it requires some code to close the database connection after fork. If option 1 is a good option, then we could implement a hybrid, where the database is quickly checked early, but a new connection is opened after fork. This would be a simple solution however.

I'm going to think some more about this and see if I can come up with a simpler and cleaner solution."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-21 20:43:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

My immediate thought is that option 2 is the best path forward. I don't like doing funky things with db connections - whether its initializing late or opening/killing/re-opening them. I'll think about how we can rewrite this one test to be more precise about what it is asserting."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-08-29 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-08-29 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 14:31:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 15:34:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 15:37:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

So I really want to fix the bug referenced in the commit message for Folsom. I think there is a lot of work we can do to improve our testing practices but that will have to wait until Grizzly.

What I've done to get this test to pass is set expect_launch=True in the call to start_with_retry. That is going to allow us to assert that the server binds but immediately dies, where before it wasn't even binding before death.

Are we okay with this as a temporary fix to get this critical bug fixed?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-29 16:10:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

The problem with just expecting the service to launch in the test is that it depends on timing. The service still dies, just after the socket is listening, so there is still a race condition that could be lost.

I suspect that's why the python 2.7 unit tests failed this time."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-09-04 04:04:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-09-04 04:07:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Ok, so rather than not get this bug fixed, I decided to turn down the level of assertions in this problem test. Rather than expect a specific outcome of the call to server.start(), I've removed the expectation (since it is the most fragile). Now, the test attempts to start the server then waits for the process to die. I feel like that is an appropriate level of assertion for the functionality being tested here anyways - that a server with --respawn doesn't respawn forever."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-04 04:20:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Instantiate wsgi app for each worker

A single WSGI app, and therefore a single sqlalchemy engine (mysql
connection), was being used across all API workers. This patch
instantiates the WSGI app once per worker rather than up front to
give a separate database connection to each worker.

Fixes bug 1036193

Change-Id: I2cbb61fd88a6ec4fb03fa84196ba0a380b3842d0

[{'created': '2012-09-04 21:19:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix lack of L3 support of Ryu plugin

VMs cannot access the external network without l3 support.

Fixes bug 1043746

Change-Id: I6bd2cb69ba80ce3c799f346ca67c17ff77244ba4
'}, {'created': '2012-09-04 21:19:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix lack of L3 support of Ryu plugin

VMs cannot access the external network without l3 support.

Fixes bug 1043746

Ryu needs network-id of the interface to decide interface to
transfer a packet. The l3-agent does not give network-id to an
interface driver and there is no way to get network-id of the
interface in a driver. Therefore I modified l3-agent.

Change-Id: I6bd2cb69ba80ce3c799f346ca67c17ff77244ba4
'}, {'created': '2012-09-04 21:19:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix lack of L3 support of Ryu plugin

VMs cannot access the external network without l3 support.

Fixes bug 1043746

Ryu needs network-id of the interface to decide interface to
transfer a packet. The l3-agent does not give network-id to an
interface driver and there is no way to get network-id of the
interface in a driver. Therefore I modified l3-agent.

Change-Id: I6bd2cb69ba80ce3c799f346ca67c17ff77244ba4
'}]
commit_message:
Fix lack of L3 support of Ryu plugin

VMs cannot access the external network without l3 support.

Fixes bug 1043746

Change-Id: I6bd2cb69ba80ce3c799f346ca67c17ff77244ba4

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-08-29 22:37:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This looks okay. I just want to make sure I understand whats going on since db migrations are operationally very important.

I just want to check to see if the following is true:
- All actual deployments should already have the timestamp columns, they just were created by register_models (or somesuch) rather than explicitly in the migration.
- Because of that we don't need to load any data into the new columns because if there are any rows present, the columns are also already present.

Sounds right?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 22:56:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 22:57:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add missing columns to migration 14

This adds created_at, updated_at, and deleted_at to database
migration 14.

Background Info!

If a new database is created at version 14, it doesn't run any
migrations scripts. It lets sqlalchemy create the database from a
set of sqlalchemy models.

When an existing database is upgraded to version 14, it will use
the migration script. What's important to note is that this is
currently impossible due to bug 1042925.

While it is typically bad practice to alter a migration script, this
is a special case as nobody could have used it. What this patch does
is complete the migration script in preparation for a future patch
down the road to fix the bug referenced above.

Fixes bug 1043041

Change-Id: I6dc2afa735fb2f82df71d58b10c1e1530fce2f89

commit_message:
On rebuild, the compute.instance.exists

notification should contain the original image
metadata.

In order to do this, the original system metadata associated
with the instance is preserved and passed along to the
rebuild_instance() in the compute manager.

(Code originally from Iccha Sethi and Rick Harris.)

bug 1044008

Change-Id: Ieb60a2871a2a209ef467e2b51dab375872649a18

commit_message:
WARN and use defaults when no policy file is found

Rather than refuse to start, it's nicer to use a sane set of default
policies when no policy file is found.

Fixes bug 1043482

Change-Id: I849737c61c0266952d931395fbc2ad3745c46f6e

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-08-28 21:55:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I love the logging additions and Waldon does bring up a good point in that we're not really using the ContextAdapter very much right now. I'm really confused how it works in the first place...but I'd very much like to see these changes go in.

Perhaps we can get some research done on utilizing the ContextAdapter (I think that's the piece we need to look at) but in the meanwhile get these log improvements in."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-28 22:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

My point is that the request-id/user/tenant should already be part of the log line. The ContextAdapter thing is already being used. We just need to log the actions that are happening. Notice how the user is duplicated in the line below:

  2012-08-28 15:56:37 DEBUG glance.registry.api.v1.images [73d8bf4c-8989-4816-b4ac-7c080b169cfb 1704aafc-b691-4a7c-9cd0-f20f4f9df67b de96b8be-2f45-421b-a4c5-2aa0d778aeea] Successfully deleted image 82ef9af7-92bf-495a-8276-ce85d7ebf2a8 for user 1704aafc-b691-4a7c-9cd0-f20f4f9df67b from (pid=53584) delete /Users/bcwaldon/src/glance/glance/registry/api/v1/images.py:304'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-28 23:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you add a log line for a call to index?'}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2012-08-29 14:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

The glance registry also currently prints all the sql queries, do we want to get rid of them to improve readability of logs? Or keep them for now.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 14:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Keep them for now. The sqlalchemy log level is based off of the 'debug' argument, but it should really use something else. I don't want to change the configuration of this right now since we're in a feature freeze."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2012-08-29 17:26:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm rewriting the log messages to only include info that is not in the context object.  Two questions:
1. Should these be INFO or DEBUG level messages?  I'm logging the successes as well as problems, and don't want to fill up the logs.
2. What kind of message is good for the 'index' and 'detail' calls?  I'm thinking we don't want the list of image IDs, or maybe we do?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-08-29 17:42:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

INFO is an appropriate level for what you're adding. Think of INFO as documenting what's happening and DEBUG for data that would be useful when debugging a problem. For the index/detail calls, I would expect you to log an INFO-level 'index is being called' sort of deal."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2012-08-29 21:07:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-29 21:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Adds registry logging

The registry API currently only logs the sqlalchemy debug output. Added
log messages at the API level.

Fixes bug 1041238

Change-Id: I90f015ad26cd67a449dfa0fa0697f94d493644bf

commit_message:
Fix bug where image size is incorrectly rejected.

Fixes bug 1043952.

Added GB-1 (one byte less than a gig) to the numerator to
correct round-off errors.

Change-Id: I6d97f3c53ab5a8ff5a0752400fd189f23223958f

Fixed PEP8 complaints.

Change-Id: Iacecddd4e65c80964f4860d6580872d897ec2356

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-17 10:24:06.000000000', 'message': 'Make size optional when creating a volume from a snapshot

When creating a volume from a snapshot, the size should be optional,
with the assumption being that the new volume should be the same
size as the volume that originally got snapshotted.

To be honest, the size argument should not be there at all, but
removing it breaks back-compatability.

Change-Id: I3fea7fe1c0415d10e549c66a242cf2a336a7204e
'}, {'created': '2012-08-27 17:18:25.000000000', 'message': "Make size optional when creating a volume from a snap

Changing the size of a volume when cloning a snapshot doesn't
make a great deal of sense *and isn't part of the ec2 api).

This patch makes the field optional, defaulting to the same
size as the snapshot (and therefore the origination volume).

Change-Id: I3fea7fe1c0415d10e549c66a242cf2a336a7204e
"}, {'created': '2012-08-30 16:29:36.000000000', 'message': "Make size optional when creating a volume from a snap

Changing the size of a volume when cloning a snapshot doesn't
make a great deal of sense *and isn't part of the ec2 api).

This patch makes the field optional, defaulting to the same
size as the snapshot (and therefore the origination volume).

Change-Id: I3fea7fe1c0415d10e549c66a242cf2a336a7204e
"}, {'created': '2012-08-31 15:58:58.000000000', 'message': "Make size optional when creating a volume from a snap

Changing the size of a volume when cloning a snapshot doesn't
make a great deal of sense *and isn't part of the ec2 api).

This patch makes the field optional, defaulting to the same
size as the snapshot (and therefore the origination volume).

Change-Id: I3fea7fe1c0415d10e549c66a242cf2a336a7204e
"}]
commit_message:
Make size optional when creating a volume from a snap

Changing the size of a volume when cloning a snapshot doesn't
make a great deal of sense *and isn't part of the ec2 api).

This patch makes the field optional, defaulting to the same
size as the snapshot (and therefore the origination volume).

Change-Id: I3fea7fe1c0415d10e549c66a242cf2a336a7204e

commit_message:
Add bin/ceilometer-api for convenience

This is a bit more obvious than running the module.
I have basically just moved api/__main__.py into bin/ceilometer-api.

Change-Id: I50d614ea98b278563b576e0b3b9df03b391e2152
Signed-off-by: Angus Salkeld <asalkeld@redhat.com>

( I'm not sure yet )"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 27.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27:

I fixed your point'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28: Works for me

[Basically same as the previous comment. I commented on patch set 27 by mistake, so inline comments are not published.]

I could not reproduce mark's problem too.
Mark, I would like to clarify the detail. Does the first ping-all succeed if you wait for a while after creating a subnet or always fail after creating a subnet? In the former case setting up a port for dnsmasq takes a time and in the latter setting a probe take a while I think.
My inline comment is a minor issue. We do not necessarily need to fix it."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 28.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

Mark and I talked about this on IRC.  The basic functionality seems to work as described, so we are going to approve it.  There are several areas where we think the functionality can be improved in Grizzly though, so we're viewing this as 'experimental' in Folsom.  The important points about marking something 'experimental' is that 1) bugs found in this feature are not going to block a release 2) it is possible that in grizzly we will make non-backward compatible changes to how this feature works."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

It is nice ping-all ignores probe-port.

The long journey of this patch is arriving at the goal. I hope the problem Mark encountered will be resolved soon. Cheers!'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I set debug and verbose to False in my .ini file and starting quantum-debug dumps the keystone request to the screen.  It should honor these settings.  This is caused by using basicConfig in the wrong place.

The output for probe-list is too verbose.  It should be closer to the output 
of port-list."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

ENABLED_SERVICES+=,q-svc,q-agt,q-dhcp,q-l3

NOVA_USE_QUANTUM_API=v2
SERVICE_TOKEN=1234TOKEN5678
ADMIN_PASSWORD=secret
SERVICE_PASSWORD=password
MYSQL_PASSWORD=anothersecret
RABBIT_PASSWORD=yetanothersecret
NETWORK_GATEWAY=192.168.57.1
FIXED_RANGE=192.168.57.0/24"}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2012-09-04 17:55:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Nachi-  Thanks for being patient with this review.  Things look a lot better.  A few bumps left to smooth out, but getting super close. 

When I run ping-all for an OVS network that does not have a probe, the command will fail the first time that it is run.  It works on subsequent runs.  I'm guessing this is due to the agent not configuring the device in time.  We need to figure out a solution to avoid this race condition which causes the ping failure.

commit_message:
Implements agent for Quantum Networking testing

This agent client plugs itself into each network.
Then tries to ping each fixed_ips.
Implements blueprint test-agent

Change-Id: I3908e37401272e9e091ceae66e72cfcdd13b7898

commit_message:
heat tests : Add verify_wordpress helper function

Functional tests : Add a new VerifyStack class and retry decorator,
which allows easy implementation of tests for stack successful creation.

Initial simple verify_wordpress function scrapes a wordpress homepage
and looks for a known string in the html result.

Change-Id: I32bd4bea04228c4f393894c65d040d55c65ddbca
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
heat tests : FuncUtils add get_stack_output function

Add a function to FuncUtils which allows us to easily parse
the stack outputs defined in a template

[{'created': '2012-09-04 16:02:21.000000000', 'message': 'heat tools : add qpid-cpp-server-daemon to tools/openstack

As of qpid-cpp-server-0.16-5 the service scripts have been
moved to a separate qpid-cpp-server-daemon package, so add
this to the list of required packages for openstack install

Fixes : #219

Change-Id: I6c8b53a69953c543df7cd68637e4ff5e4ca495ad
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat tools : add qpid-cpp-server-daemon to tools/openstack

As of qpid-cpp-server-0.16-5 the service scripts have been
moved to a separate qpid-cpp-server-daemon package, so add
this to the list of required packages for openstack install

Fixes : #219

Change-Id: I6c8b53a69953c543df7cd68637e4ff5e4ca495ad
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
HACKING compliance & staticly init module vars

- HACKING: "When defining global constants, define them before functions
  and classes"
- Statically initializing other module variables to None

Change-Id: I8d01e179262a8b16dbe49edef8e23260970c84a0

The db.reservation_expire() function assumes a 'usage' attribute on
Reservation objects, but we don't actually define that relationship.

The end result is that reservation_expire() currently traceback if
it actually needs to expire any reservations. This happens pretty
rarely since reservations should only need expiring if they are
leaked because of another bug.

Also define a test case to actually excercise the expiration code
path.

commit_message:
Fix quota reservation expiration

Fixes bug #1040942

The db.reservation_expire() function assumes a 'usage' attribute on
Reservation objects, but we don't actually define that relationship.

The end result is that reservation_expire() currently traceback if
it actually needs to expire any reservations. This happens pretty
rarely since reservations should only need expiring if they are
leaked because of another bug.

Also define a test case to actually excercise the expiration code
path.

Add a missing chain-up to tearDown in test_limits which was causing
the get_project_quotas() stub not to be unset and, in turn, the
reservation expiration test to fail.

Change-Id: Ib61dbf9fd5dfb5badaf05f20c423a69925d83754

use simplejson to serialize acct/cont results

I did some benchmarking, and it's just a lot faster to use simplejson
to serialize account and container listings.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-04 07:11:26.000000000', 'message': 'Update zmq context cleanup to use term.

Updates the RPC cleanup function for the zmq RPC driver
to use Context.term() instead of Context.destroy().

This allows the Nova code to work with older versions (pre 2.1.10)
of pyzmq. The Context term() function seems to do the job just as well as
destroy() (and is also thread safe) so lets just use it instead.

Fixes LP Bug #1044004.

Change-Id: Ifadd2c19914abfe5dbb58310d21eb6c78563fb82
'}]
commit_message:
Update zmq context cleanup to use term.

Updates the RPC cleanup function for the zmq RPC driver
to use Context.term() instead of Context.destroy().

This allows the Nova code to work with older versions (pre 2.1.10)
of pyzmq. The Context term() function seems to do the job just as well as
destroy() (and is also thread safe) so lets just use it instead.

Fixes LP Bug #1044004.

Change-Id: Ifadd2c19914abfe5dbb58310d21eb6c78563fb82

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-09-04 07:11:10.000000000', 'message': 'Allow non-string items in the creds dict.

The generic checking in policy allows us to match against data from the
creds_dict using a very simple syntax. For example, in policy.json if
you had something like:

"some_action": [["project_id:foo"]]

it would only allow project foo to perform that action, but something
like:

"some_action": [["is_admin:True"]]

where is_admin is a boolean fails.

This modifies the check to convert the value to unicode before
attempting to compare it. It includes a test.

Fixes bug 1039132

Change-Id: I0e53a6ea2709212d4a1536f901bcf1e717a232ca
'}]
commit_message:
Allow non-string items in the creds dict.

The generic checking in policy allows us to match against data from the
creds_dict using a very simple syntax. For example, in policy.json if
you had something like:

"some_action": [["project_id:foo"]]

it would only allow project foo to perform that action, but something
like:

"some_action": [["is_admin:True"]]

where is_admin is a boolean fails.

This modifies the check to convert the value to unicode before
attempting to compare it. It includes a test.

Fixes bug 1039132

Change-Id: I0e53a6ea2709212d4a1536f901bcf1e717a232ca

Add nosehtmloutput as a test dependency.

results to an html file. This will be used by Jenkins to save logs on
a different server.

[{'created': '2012-09-04 07:10:20.000000000', 'message': 'Regarding the mispelling of the Noble Narwhal.

The narwhal, or narwhale, Monodon monoceros, is a medium-sized toothed whale
that lives year-round in the Arctic. One of two living species of whale in
the Monodontidae family, along with the beluga whale, narwhal males are
distinguished by a long, straight, helical tusk, actually an elongated upper
left canine. Found primarily in Canadian Arctic and Greenlandic waters,
rarely south of 65°N latitude, the narwhal is a uniquely specialized Arctic
predator. In the winter, it feeds on benthic prey, mostly flatfish, at
depths of up to 1500 m under dense pack ice.  Narwhals have been harvested
for over a thousand years by Inuit people in northern Canada and Greenland
for meat and ivory, and a regulated subsistence hunt continues to this day.
While populations appear stable, the narwhal has been deemed particularly
vulnerable to climate change due to a narrow geographical range and
specialized diet.

Via Wikipedia

Change-Id: I0aa6fb9a29f6e851eb2621d70d400e1505ae2d32
(cherry picked from commit 33c9880421bdb877005a9c8579d92bf7a96b66ea)
'}]
commit_message:
Regarding the mispelling of the Noble Narwhal.

The narwhal, or narwhale, Monodon monoceros, is a medium-sized toothed whale
that lives year-round in the Arctic. One of two living species of whale in
the Monodontidae family, along with the beluga whale, narwhal males are
distinguished by a long, straight, helical tusk, actually an elongated upper
left canine. Found primarily in Canadian Arctic and Greenlandic waters,
rarely south of 65°N latitude, the narwhal is a uniquely specialized Arctic
predator. In the winter, it feeds on benthic prey, mostly flatfish, at
depths of up to 1500 m under dense pack ice.  Narwhals have been harvested
for over a thousand years by Inuit people in northern Canada and Greenland
for meat and ivory, and a regulated subsistence hunt continues to this day.
While populations appear stable, the narwhal has been deemed particularly
vulnerable to climate change due to a narrow geographical range and
specialized diet.

Via Wikipedia

Change-Id: I0aa6fb9a29f6e851eb2621d70d400e1505ae2d32
(cherry picked from commit 33c9880421bdb877005a9c8579d92bf7a96b66ea)

commit_message:
Don't trap then re-raise ImportError.

When we catch ImportError, print a message, and then raise a new ImportError,
we lose sane ability to read the traceback, and we gain nothing. Raising a new
ImportError on Attribute or Value error is helpful, given the context in which
we are working.

Set default branch in .gitreview to stable/folsom
